channel.title: NYT > World > Middle East

item.title: Hamas Elevates Gaza Leader Who Planned Oct. 7 Attacks to Top Post
item.description: The selection of Yahya Sinwar, a prime target of Israeli forces, to replace the assassinated Ismail Haniyeh consolidates authority in the hands of a hard-liner who is in hiding.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar will replace Ismail Haniyeh as the next head of Hamas’s political office. He is seen here in Gaza City in 2023.

item.title: Who Is Yahya Sinwar, Hamas’s New Political Leader?
item.description: Mr. Sinwar, one of the main architects of the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel, has spent decades with the militant group, working his way to the top of its leadership.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, in Gaza City in 2023, has long been viewed as one of Hamas’s most influential leaders, wielding outsize power while remaining mostly in hiding in underground tunnels.

item.title: Iran Executes Protester Reza Rasaei After Trial Condemned by Rights Groups
item.description: Weeks after Iran elected a reformist leader, the authorities executed Reza Rasaei, who was arrested during protests that swept the country in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Wana News Agency
item.media:description: Antigovernment protests swept across Iran in 2022. A man who was arrested during that period was executed by the Iranian authorities on Tuesday.

item.title: Waiting for a Wider War, Lebanese Civilians Feel Helpless
item.description: Hezbollah’s conflict with Israel has already damaged south Lebanon. Now it could escalate, regardless of what anyone else in Lebanon thinks.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Hwaida Saad and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah members and supporters mourned the deaths of Amer Dagher and his two sisters, Fawzia and Taghreed, who were killed in their home in an Israeli attack on July 15.

item.title: As Israel Braces for Iran’s Retaliation, Diplomats Scramble
item.description: President Biden convened his national security team and spoke with King Abdullah II of Jordan, and foreign ministers from Islamic countries plan to gather in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Hamas and Hezbollah drove through the streets of Saida, Lebanon, following tributes for the slain Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and the Hezbollah commander Fuad Shukr on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Troops in Iraq Are Wounded in Rocket Attack on Air Base
item.description: The attack late Monday resembled previous ones carried out by Iraqi armed groups, backed by Iran, which have targeted the base repeatedly over the past nine months.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: U.N. Fires Nine Aid Workers Accused of Taking Part in Oct. 7 Attack, but Clears 10 Others
item.description: Israel accused 19 UNRWA employees of playing a role in the Hamas-led raids that set off the war. Investigators cleared 10 for lack of evidence, but said the other nine “may have been involved.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Ephrat Livni
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians receiving food aid at the UNRWA center in Rafah, Gaza, in January.

item.title: Why Is Iran Expected to Attack Israel? Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Iran has vowed to retaliate for the killing of a senior Hamas leader in Tehran last week, an attack for which it has blamed Israel.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians gathered in Tehran last week after the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, a top Hamas leader.

item.title: Israeli Strike on Gaza Shelter Kills at Least 30
item.description: An Israeli airstrike in Gaza City killed at least 30 people, according to a Palestinian emergency agency and local media outlets. Israel said it targeted Hamas “command and control centers.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Iyad Abuheweila and Ameera Harouda
item.media:credit: Mahmoud Issa/Reuters
item.media:description: In a still image taken from a video, Palestinians carried a person at the site of an Israeli strike on Sunday on a school sheltering displaced people in Gaza City.

item.title: Netanyahu Says Israel Was Already in a ‘War Against Iran’s Evil Axis’
item.description: A number of international airlines have suspended flights to and from Israel pending expected retaliation against the country by Iran and its Lebanese proxy, Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner

item.title: Hamas May Emerge Battered, but Not Beaten, From Israel’s Latest Blows
item.description: The assassinations of two Hamas leaders may be a short-term setback, analysts say, not enough to prevent the group from re-emerging intact — and possibly more radicalized.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamas supporters parading with empty coffins in a symbolic funeral for Ismail Haniyeh, a top Hamas leader, on Friday in Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Two are dead after a stabbing attack near Tel Aviv.
item.description: Officials called the Sunday morning attack “complex and difficult,” with the victims in separate but nearby locations. The suspected attacker also died.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Ricardo Moraes/Reuters
item.media:description: Emergency responders at the scene of a stabbing in Holon, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Hezbollah and Israel Exchange Limited Fire Over the Border
item.description: The attack from Lebanon did not appear to be the major retaliation that Hezbollah has threatened in the wake of the Israeli assassination of a senior commander.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar
item.media:credit: Rabih Daher/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the site of an Israeli strike on the southern Lebanese village of Taybeh on Sunday.

item.title: Can Kamala Harris Win Back Arab American Voters?
item.description: Vice President Kamala Harris has not strayed from President Biden on Israel policy, but she has taken a stronger tone on the suffering of Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I was torn,” Muna Jondy said about voting for President Biden. Vice President Kamala Harris’s ascension helped ease those concerns.

item.title: Killing of Hamas Leader Fuels More Tension Between Biden and Netanyahu
item.description: President Biden has expressed concern that the circumstances of the assassination have thrown cease-fire talks into doubt, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel rejects that idea, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has clashed with President Biden over Israel’s prosecution of the war in Gaza.

item.title: Israel Conducts Airstrikes on West Bank, Killing 3 Hamas Military Wing Members
item.description: Israel hit a town in the occupied West Bank with two airstrikes on Saturday in the latest use of a once-rare tactic in the densely populated area.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Majdi Mohammed/Associated Press
item.media:description: A car was destroyed in a drone strike in the West Bank on Saturday.

item.title: The Pentagon promises to help defend Israel.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III in Washington in May.

item.title: Iran Arrests Dozens After Killing of Hamas Leader Haniyeh
item.description: Iran has begun a sweeping investigation into the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, with its intensity a sign of how damaging and shocking the security failure was.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral for Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran on Friday; the Hamas leader was assassinated in Iran’s capital on Wednesday.

item.title: Alongside the Trump-Russia Inquiry, a Lesser-Known Look at Egyptian Influence
item.description: The Justice Department and special counsel Robert Mueller investigated whether a Trump adviser was part of an Egyptian plan, never proven, to funnel $10 million to the 2016 Trump campaign.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Adam Goldman and Glenn Thrush
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Stephen Crowley/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump and President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt outside the White House in 2017.

item.title: Ismail Haniyeh, Hamas Leader, Is Buried in Qatar Amid Mourning in Turkey and Gaza
item.description: Few Palestinians appeared to heed Hamas’s call for a “day of anger” to condemn the killing of Ismail Haniyeh and Israel’s bombardment of the enclave.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Victoria Kim and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamas supporters paraded on Tuesday in Beirut, Lebanon, with empty coffins in a symbolic funeral for the Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh.

item.title: Families of Hostages in Gaza Despair As Assassination Halts Talks
item.description: The recent assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, the leader of Hamas’s political branch, halted negotiations for a cease-fire that would bring home the hostages held in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Ilan Rosenberg/Reuters
item.media:description: Supporters of the hostages being held in Gaza released 300 lanterns Thursday in Tel Aviv to mark 300 days since the deadly Oct. 7 attack.

item.title: U.S. to Send More Combat Aircraft to Middle East as Iran Threatens Israel
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III directed the new deployments after speaking with his Israeli counterpart.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Song Kyung-Seok
item.media:description: The aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt, seen in South Korea in June, is now steaming near the Arabian Gulf, equipped with about 40 F/A-18 Super Hornet and F-35 attack planes.

item.title: Many of Gaza’s Medical Workers Have Been Detained or Killed
item.description: Out of a prewar total of about 20,000 health workers, 500 have been killed in the war, according to the W.H.O., and more than 300 are in Israeli detention, Gaza’s health ministry says.
item.dc:creator: Anjana Sankar
item.media:credit: Haitham Imad/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A doctor inspecting damage at Nasser Hospital, in Khan Younis, Gaza.

item.title: Israel Confirms Death of Muhammad Deif, Who It Says Helped Planned Hamas Attack
item.description: The Israeli military said it had killed Muhammad Deif, who it called a planner of the Oct. 7 attack on Israel, which would make him the third Iranian-backed militant leader slain in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Farnaz Fassihi, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters on Thursday carried the coffin of a commander, Fuad Shukr, who was killed in an Israeli airstrike in the southern suburbs of Beirut.

item.title: Hezbollah Leader Threatens Retaliation Against Israel After Airstrike Near Beirut
item.description: Nasrallah delivered a televised address at the funeral of a Hezbollah commander who was killed in an Israeli strike in suburban Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, seen on a video screen at the funeral for Fuad Shukr, a Hezbollah commander, in Beirut, Lebanon, on Thursday.

item.title: How Hamas Leader Ismail Haniyeh Was Killed in Iran
item.description: An explosive device hidden in a heavily guarded complex where Ismail Haniyeh was known to stay in Iran was what killed him, according to a Times investigation.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Mark Mazzetti and Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Security Concerns Grow for Israeli Olympians in Paris
item.description: Concerns for the Israeli team — which has been shrouded in protection at every Games since 1972 — have substantially increased since the Oct. 7 terrorist attacks and the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg and Johnatan Reiss
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Security officers before a soccer game last week at the Olympics in Paris.

item.title: Fears of Wider Mideast Conflict Deepen, With U.S. Seen as ‘Not in Control’
item.description: American officials said they had no advance warning of the attack on the Hamas leader in Iran, raising worries of a power vacuum that could lead to a broader geopolitical crisis.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Tehran on Wednesday held Iranian and Palestinian flags and images of Ismail Haniyeh, the Hamas leader who was killed in the city that morning.

item.title: Muhammad Deif, a Top Hamas Commander, Is Dead, Israel Says
item.description: Mr. Deif has survived several previous Israeli assassination attempts and has been the No. 2 Hamas leader in Gaza. Israel said it killed him in a strike last month in southern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Iran’s Options for Retaliation Risk Escalating Middle East Crisis
item.description: The killing of Hamas’s political leader in Tehran was a humiliating security failure for the Iranian government.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Masoud Pezeshkian of Iran during his swearing-in ceremony in Tehran on Tuesday.

item.title: Assassination of a top Hamas leader spurs rallies worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

item.title: Iran and Hamas Blame Israel for Killing of Ismail Haniyeh, and Vow Revenge
item.description: The deadly strike on Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran threatened to further inflame the region and derail negotiations aimed at reaching a cease-fire in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Adam Rasgon, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carrying Palestinian flags and chanting “death to Israel” in Tehran on Wednesday, in protest over the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, a Hamas leader.

item.title: Back-to-Back Assassinations in Middle East Scramble Biden’s Hopes for Peace
item.description: President Biden had anticipated using his remaining time in office to finally bring an end to the war in Gaza. But that was Monday.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A young Hamas supporter carrying a flag to pay tribute to Ismail Haniyeh, the organization’s political leader, who was killed in Iran on Wednesday.

item.title: Two Al Jazeera Journalists Were Killed in an Israeli Strike on Gaza
item.description: A reporter and a cameraman were working from or near the house of Ismail Haniyeh, the Hamas political chief who was assassinated on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Ayman Al Hassi/Reuters
item.media:description: Palestinians inspect a vehicle where Al Jazeera TV said its reporter Ismail al-Ghoul and cameraman Ramy El Rify were killed in an Israeli strike, in Gaza City July 31, 2024.

item.title: Iran’s Leader Orders Attack on Israel for Haniyeh Killing, Officials Say
item.description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, ordered retaliation after a humiliating security failure, as Iran once again balances showing strength against the risk of escalation.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Images of Ismail Haniyeh, a senior Hamas leader who was assassinated in Iran on Wednesday, at a square in Tehran.

item.title: Unrest at Israeli Army Bases Highlights Battle for Country’s Soul
item.description: After Israeli soldiers were detained on suspicion of abusing a Palestinian, riots broke out that symbolize a wider struggle over Israel’s future that has divided the country.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman and Natan Odenheimer
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Right-wing protesters demonstrate against the arrest of Israeli soldiers at Beit Lid military base, Israel.

item.title: How Will a Hamas Leader’s Killing Affect Gaza Cease-Fire Talks?
item.description: Ismail Haniyeh, who was assassinated in Iran, was a key figure in Hamas’s cease-fire negotiations with Israel and his assassination makes the prospects for a deal even more unclear.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israelis in Tel Aviv marked nine months in July since the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas.

item.title: After Haniyeh’s Death, Who Are Hamas’s Most Prominent Leaders?
item.description: Ismail Haniyeh, who was killed in Iran, was among the most senior members of Hamas’s leadership. Here is a look at others.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, head of the political bureau of Hamas, delivering a speech in 2023 in Gaza City.

item.title: Strikes in Iran and Lebanon Raise Risk of Escalation, but All-Out War Is Not Inevitable
item.description: The scale of the reaction from Iran and its regional proxies to the attacks on two of Israel’s largest foes could determine whether the low-level regional battle tips into a full-scale conflict.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives and Hezbollah supporters carrying the coffins of Amira, 6, and her brother Hassan Fadlallah, 10, who were killed in an Israeli airstrike in Dahiyeh, a suburb of Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Haniyeh’s Death Will Shake but Not Destroy Hamas, Analysts Say
item.description: Hamas will need to scramble to replace Ismail Haniyeh following his killing in Tehran, analysts say, but the group has recovered from past assassinations of its political and military leaders.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ismail Haniyeh, center, in Gaza City in 2012. Mr. Haniyeh was one of Hamas’s most recognizable faces worldwide.

item.title: Will the Assassination of a Hamas Leader Escalate the Risk of a Wider War?
item.description: Qatar and Egypt, the main mediators in talks to end the Gaza war, have warned that new assassinations risk plunging the region even deeper into chaos.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Professors gather in front of the University of Tehran on Wednesday to protest the assassination of the Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh.

item.title: Iran Has Accused Israel of Assassinations on Its Soil Before
item.description: Iran has blamed Israel for a series of targeted killings carried out within its borders.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iran accused Israel of killing Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, a scientist described as a leading figure in its nuclear weapons program, in 2020.

item.title: Ismail Haniyeh, a Top Hamas Leader, Is Dead at 62
item.description: Mr. Haniyeh, the Palestinian militant group’s exiled political chief, managed high-stakes negotiations, including the ongoing cease-fire talks to end the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ismail Haniyeh, a senior Hamas leader, was in Tehran on Tuesday for the inauguration ceremony of Iran’s new president.

item.title: War Gives Palestinian Olympians a Wider Role: Athlete-Diplomats
item.description: The Israel-Hamas war has given the eight Palestinians competing in Paris Olympics a higher profile than usual.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: The boxer Wasim Abusal competed with a Palestinian flag on his top.

item.title: What We Know About the Assassination of Hamas Leader Ismail Haniyeh
item.description: The top Hamas leader, who was central to the group’s high-stakes negotiations and diplomacy, was killed in Iran’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Vahid Salemi/Associated Press
item.media:description: Ismail Haniyeh, a top Hamas leader, in Tehran in March.

item.title: Israel Says It Killed Hezbollah Commander in Airstrike Near Beirut
item.description: The strike was in retaliation for a deadly rocket attack this weekend in the Golan Heights. At least three civilians were killed and 74 others wounded on Tuesday, Lebanese officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Adam Rasgon, Euan Ward, Farnaz Fassihi and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Hussein Malla/Associated Press
item.media:description: A destroyed building in the southern suburbs of Beirut, Lebanon, after an Israeli strike on Tuesday. At least one person was killed.
